Stanekzai (acting defense minister) is replaced as caretaker defence minister by General Abdullah Khan, previously chief of staff at the ministry.
These changes were made public in two different presidential decrees during the night of 5 to 6 May 2016.  With this, Abdullah Khan replaces Stanakzai, who has been acting as defence minister ever since the Afghan parliament denied him its vote of confidence in early July 2015. Abdullah Khan, who is already the fifth NUG candidate for the top defence job, had already been picked once before (he was third in this line at the time) but was never officially introduced to parliament. (It is not clear why, although it might have had to do with his lacklustre mujahedin background). The fact that he has yet to be rejected might make him acceptable to the parliamentarians who, over the past years, have blocked many attempts, mainly by Ghani’s predecessor Hamed Karzai, to re-introduce candidates already voted down. The filling of these two positions has been a recurring demand of both houses of parliament (see this AAN analysis) (both led by politicians who are close to the new quasi-opposition), but also of donor countries. Ghani is expected to attend the 2016 NATO summit in Warsaw in early July 2016, and it would cost him a degree of credibility in those circles (who, off the record, are all but uncritical about the NUG’s poor performance so far) if he, in spite of repeated promises, were to show up with those two positions still vacant. The other key positions, which were vacant for a long time, that of interior minister and attorney general, were filled in April 2016.
Lieutenant General Abdullah Khan, whose penultimate position was chief of personnel in the ANA’s general staff, comes across as a good choice to succeed Stanakzai at the MoD. According to officials both in the National Security Council and the Resolute Support Mission, he enjoys a reputation of professionalism, attaining high marks in his military training (including in the Soviet Union), and clean hands.

@einsteinjs has provided such a comprehensive rationale below that it is difficult to find anything additional to say. After the last Presidential elections, the Abdullah group alleged fraud and refused to accept defeat, even after an internationally supervised "audit" of the votes. The present forced compromise with Abdullah as Chief Executive and Ghani as President papered over their differences, but it keeps showing up in cases like this, as Parliament is also divided. Whenever the Abdullah group feels its preferences have been ignored, it will attempt to use Parliament to block implementation, while the US has stopped trying to bang heads together. Unless there is a major external threat that unites the two groups ( e.g. Taliban successes in the field next spring), a change in the status quo seems unlikely. The mistrust between the groups is so great that the next elections are unlikely until all pre-election issues, starting from re-verification of the voters lists, are agreed and done (I remember from last year that the number of voters' cards issued exceeded the number of registered voters by over 50%).

The biggest and maybe most important data point here is that the Afghan Parliament is... in flux. There was supposed to be an election this year (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Afghan_parliamentary_election,_2015 ), but it looks like that might not happen until next year. Despite the need for elections, there is still a Parliament (http://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/20/world/asia/afghan-parliaments-term-is-extended-after-squabbles-delay-elections.html ), but there's some question as to the legitmacy. If we take a step back, Pres. Ghani has tried to confirm three (!) Defence Ministers. The last one (and current Acting) didn't go well (http://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/23/world/asia/taliban-attack-afghan-parliament-and-seize-a-2nd-district-in-north.html ) as the Taliban bombed Parliament during what would have been the confirmation. Right now, the guy that the Pres. was trying to have confirmed is the acting DM (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohammed_Masoom_Stanekzai ). Again, he's the ACTING DM. List of Afghani DMs -- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Defense_(Afghanistan) \\ So, it seems unlikely that there'll be a "sitting of Parliament" to confirm the current Acting DM. Meaning, this question is, essentially, a proxy for whether we think that there will be Afghani elections before the Summer of 2016 (giving them time to pick and then confirm a Cabinet. I found this Q&A (http://asiafoundation.org/in-asia/2015/11/18/looking-ahead-in-afghanistan-a-conversation-with-political-economist-timor-sharan/ ) helpful in understanding the situation in Afghanistan as it relates to electoral reform. Excerpt: You said that one of the major issues of the 2014 election was that there was no Afghan-led election dispute resolution mechanism in place. Ahead of possible parliamentary elections next year, how important is it that such a mechanism is in place, and what role could it play in ensuring legitimacy? The international community has invested heavily in the Afghan elections in the past 14 years. This investment has been significant both financially and politically. However, a major missing element has been an Afghan-led election dispute resolution mechanism, undermining the legitimacy of election results in Afghanistan. Without a credible dispute resolution mechanism in place, the most transparent elections in Afghanistan could theoretically lead to a dispute, with each group/candidate accusing the other of fraud and vote-rigging. Unfortunately, there are not many signs that this will change by the next parliamentary elections, especially as all bodies (i.e., the Election Reform Commission) are partisan and the AGO appointment is still pending. \\\ COMMENT: Note that it says POSSIBLE parliamentary elections.
